questions.question: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic headaches, infertility, and galactorrhea.MRI of the brain shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
Presence of which of the following features is required to diagnose a patient with pituitary carcinoma?
questions.explanation: The following features are required for the diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma: • A pituitary tumor that has metastasized to distant sites, either craniospinal or systemic sites (and/or) • Presence of a pituitary tumor that is not contiguous with the primary sellar tumor. Pituitary carcinoma is extremely rare (< 1% of total tumors). They are associated with activating mutations of the HRAS oncogene. The diagnosis of pituitary carcinoma cannot be made based on histologic appearance alone. Though pituitary adenomas normally show cellular monomorphism and the absence of a reticulin network, they can have some overlapping features with malignant tumors, such as: • Atypical adenomas - show pleomorphism and atypical mitosis • Invasive adenomas - are non-encapsulated, show local invasion into cavernous and sphenoid sinuses, dura, brain. However, they remain confined to the primary tumor site.

questions.question: 1125Which of the following cells secrete parathyroid hormone?
questions.explanation: Parathyroid hormone (PTH) is secreted by the chief cells of the parathyroid glands.The function of the parathyroids is to regulate calcium homeostasis. This gland is composed oftwo cell types:• Chief cells -•Polygonal cells with uniform nuclei and pink cytoplasm• Water-clear appearance - due to presence of large amounts of cytoplasmic glycogen• Secretory granules containing PTH•Oxyphil cells - Slightly larger cells with acidophilic cytoplasm with no known function.The following image shows the normal histology of the parathyroid gland:Parathyroid gland-Normal histology1132Parathyroid gland Normal histologyStromal fatOxyphil cellsChief cellsC-cells or parafollicular cells are present in the thyroid. They secrete calcitonin.

questions.question: What is the most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of asymptomatic hypercalcemia (isolated hypercalcemia without signs orsymptoms) is primary hyperparathyroidism. It is also the most common cause of hypercalcemiaoverall.Primary hyperparathyroidism results in autonomous overproduction of parathyroid hormone(PTH), resulting in elevated levels. It usually results from an adenoma or hyperplasia ofparathyroid tissue.The most common cause of symptomatic hypercalcemia is malignancy. The most commonmechanism through which osteolytic tumors induce hypercalcemia is the secretion of thePTH-related peptide (PTHrP).

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman presented with bone pain and abdominal cramps for the past 1 week.She has had multiple prior hospital admissions for management of recurrent renal calculi.Investigations revealed elevated serum calcium and PTH levels with reduced phosphatelevels. Which of the following is the most common pathological change responsible for thiscondition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical picture is highly suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most commoncause is a sporadic, solitary parathyroid adenoma.Parathyroid tumors may be associated with cyclin D1 gene inversions and MEN1mutations. Hyperparathyroidism refers to elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH). It is classifiedinto:-• Primary autonomous overproduction of PTH• Secondary compensatory hypersecretion of PTH in response to prolonged hypocalcemia-• Tertiary - persistent hypersecretion of PTH even after correction of prolonged hypocalcemia.(e.g. after renal transplant)1133The classical symptoms and signs of primary hyperparathyroidism are due to hypercalcemia aswell as increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels. The features of hypercalcemia are as follows:The features of elevated PTH levels are as follows:⚫ Osteitis fibrosa cystica••.•Osteopenia/osteoporosis• Hyperuricemia and gout⚫ Pseudogout• Increased production of calcitriol• Nephrolithiasis•Hypophosphatemia• AnemiaThe clinical signs associated with primary hyperparathyroidism can be remembered with themnemonic "bones, stones, groans, moans with fatigue overtones"SystemMusculoskeletalRenalGITNeuropsychiatricCardiacEctopic calcificationClinical featuresBone painSkeletal deformitiesPathological fracturesMyalgia and arthralgiaRenal stones(Calcium oxalate> calcium phosphate)Nephrocalcinosis Polyuria and dehydrationRenal failureConstipationNausea, vomiting, anorexiaAbdominal painPeptic ulcer diseaseAcute pancreatitisAnxiety, depressionCognitivedysfunctionIrritabilityHallucinationsShort QT intervalBradycardiaHypertensionCornea: Band keratopathyExtravascular tissues: calcinosisSmall arteries: calciphylaxis

questions.question: A 47-year-old woman was evaluated for chronic backache and abdominal pain. Investigationsrevealed the following. What is the most likely bone finding seen in this condition?
questions.explanation: The clinical scenario and lab findings point towards a diagnosis of hyperparathyroidism. The bonefinding associated with this condition is osteitis fibrosa cystica.This condition is also called brown tumor or von Recklinghausen disease of bone.1134In hyperparathyroidism, high levels of PTH result in increased osteoclast activity. This results inbone loss which predisposes to microfractures and secondary hemorrhages. This results in thefollowing changes:•• An influx of macrophages that form giant cells•Mass of reparative fibrous tissue• Increased vascularity, hemorrhage, and hemosiderin deposition - results in brown colorThe image given below is showing a brown tumor with numerous giant cells with interstitialhemorrhage, hemosiderin.Option A: Osteoporosis circumscripta is a large, well-defined lytic lesion seen in the skull ofpatients with Paget's disease.Option B: Fraying and cupping of the metaphysis of the bones are classically seen in patientssuffering from rickets.Option D: Punched out lytic lesions of the bone are seen in patients with multiple myeloma.

questions.question: A 46-year-old woman is referred with recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. During theevaluation, she is found to have high serum levels of insulin. Measurement of which of thefollowing can help in reaching the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario is suggestive of hypoglycemia due to hyperinsulinemia. As C-peptide is amarker of endogenous insulin secretion, its levels would help in identifying the source of insulin:• High C-peptide- excess insulin production (insulinoma)•Normal/low C-peptide - exogenous insulin administration (factitious disorder)The precursor molecule of insulin is pre-proinsulin, which gets cleaved to form proinsulin. Thisproinsulin gets cleaved to form insulin and C-peptide (by-product). Hence, both are secreted inequimolar quantities during insulin secretion. Hence, the level of C-peptide corresponds to thelevel of endogenous insulin.The levels of C-peptide decrease with the loss of °-cell mass in type 1 diabetes.1135

questions.question: A pathologist is studying a Congo red-stained slide of pancreatic tissue. He observes it underpolarized light and notes the following finding. This finding is commonly associated withwhich of the following conditions?1127
questions.explanation: 1136The image shows a Congo red-stained biopsy specimen with apple-green birefringence underpolarized microscopy. It is indicative of amyloid accumulation within the pancreatic islets. Thisis commonly associated with type 2 diabetes mellitus.Amyloid deposition begins in and around capillaries and between cells. In advanced stages, theislets may be virtually obliterated and fibrosis may also be observed.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a detrimental effect of advanced glycation end-products inpatients suffering from diabetes mellitus?

options.A: Deposition of excess basement membrane material due to TGF-° release
options.B: Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells
options.C: Increased anticoagulant effect on endothelial cells and macrophages
options.D: Increase in vascular smooth muscle cells and extracellular matrix

questions.explanation: Advanced glycation end products (AGES) result in increased procoagulant effects on endothelialcells and macrophages, not anticoagulant effects.AGES are formed by nonenzymatic reactions between intracellular glucose-derived dicarbonylprecursors with the amino groups of proteins. They bind to a specific receptor (RAGE) that isexpressed on inflammatory cells (macrophages and T cells), endothelium, and vascular smoothmuscle.The detrimental effects of the AGE-RAGE signalling axis within the vascular compartmentinclude:• Release of cytokines and growth factors, including TGF-° - leads to deposition of excessbasement membrane material•Generation of reactive oxygen species in endothelial cells.• Increased procoagulant activity on endothelial cells and macrophages..• Enhanced proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and synthesis of extracellular matrixThese effects are responsible for the microvascular and macrovascular complications in diabetesmellitus.

questions.question: What is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm?
questions.explanation: Insulinoma (°-cell tumors) is the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasm. It producessufficient insulin to induce clinically significant hypoglycemia.The three most common and distinctive clinical syndromes associated with functional pancreaticendocrine neoplasms are as follows:• Hyperinsulinism• Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (hypergastrinemia)• Multiple endocrine neoplasias (MEN)

questions.question: A 39-year-old man was referred to a higher center for further evaluation of peptic ulcerdisease refractory to high doses of proton pump inhibitors. There is a history of pituitary andparathyroid tumors in his family members. Serum gastrin level was found to be 1690 pg/ml(normal < 100) and a neuroendocrine tumor is suspected. Which of the following is falseabout this condition?

options.A: It is associated with intractable jejunal ulcers
options.B: This patient likely has a solitary tumor
options.D: Tumors usually originate in Passaro's triangle

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a gastrin-producing tumor or gastrinoma(Zollinger-Ellison syndrome). The family history of pituitary and parathyroid tumors is suggestive1137of MEN1 syndrome. This syndrome is associated with multifocal gastrinomas.On the other hand, sporadic gastrinomas are usually single.Gastrinomas usually arise in the duodenum, peripancreatic soft tissues, pancreas. The site oforigin is the duodenum when ZES is associated with MEN1. Most tumors are locally invasive andmetastasize early.Hypergastrinemia gives rise to extreme gastric acid secretion and peptic ulceration, that isrefractory to proton pump inhibitors. It results in multiple ulcers in duodenum, stomach, anduncommon areas like jejunum.

questions.question: A patient with longstanding diabetes mellitus came with complaints of bulky stools.Ultrasound abdomen showed the presence of multiple gallstones. Hypersecretion of which ofthe following leads to this presentation?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of a d-cell tumor or somatostatinoma. It results in hypersecretionof somatostatin.Somatostatin inhibits pancreatic and biliary secretions. Patients with somatostatinoma usuallypresent with vague abdominal pain along with the triad of:.-Gallstones due to bile stasis• Diabetes mellitus due to inhibition of insulin secretion-• Steatorrhea - due to inhibition of pancreatic exocrine secretion and bile secretion

questions.question: A patient presented with profuse watery diarrhea and muscle cramps for the past few weeks. The diarrhea was intractable to antibiotics and stool culture was negative for organisms. He also complained of indigestion and frequent bloating. On investigation, he was found to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. Serum potassium was 2.4 mmol/L. Upper GI endoscopy was normal. Excess of which of the following hormones leads to this condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of WDHA syndrome. It is due to hypersecretion of VIP (vasoactive-intestinal peptide). WDHA syndrome includes the following features: watery diarrhea, hypokalemia (Serum K+ < 3.5 mmol/L), and achlorhydria (bloating, indigestion, iron deficiency). Neural crest tumors, such as neuroblastomas, ganglioneuroblastoma, ganglioneuromas, and pheochromocytomas can also be associated with VIPoma syndrome.
